connectivity_metrics.ai_response:
## Summary

I analyzed inhibitory → excitatory chemical connections in circuit **2eb602ea-9ffc-42a2-9fb7-5234921343d0**, grouped by **mtype**. The analysis uses the circuit edge population **S1nonbarrel_neurons__S1nonbarrel_neurons__chemical**, pre-node set **Inhibitory**, and post-node set **Excitatory**.

---

## Overall context (from circuit structure query)

- **Circuit ID:** **2eb602ea-9ffc-42a2-9fb7-5234921343d0**
- Biophysical node populations: **S1nonbarrel_neurons**
- Virtual node populations: **POm**, **VPM**, **external_S1nonbarrel_neurons**
- Node sets available (examples): **Excitatory**, **Inhibitory**, many layer- and mtype-specific node sets (e.g., **L23_CHC**, **L2_TPC:B**, **L3_TPC:A**, etc.)
- Chemical edge populations (available):  
  - **S1nonbarrel_neurons__S1nonbarrel_neurons__chemical** (used here)  
  - **POm__S1nonbarrel_neurons__chemical**  
  - **VPM__S1nonbarrel_neurons__chemical**  
  - **external_S1nonbarrel_neurons__S1nonbarrel_neurons__chemical**

---

## Inhibitory → Excitatory connectivity (grouped by mtype)

The results returned grouped metrics for specific inhibitory mtypes (pre) onto excitatory mtypes (post). Values shown are connection probability (%) and mean number of synapses per connected pair.

| Pre (inhibitory mtype) | Post (excitatory mtype) | Connection probability (%) | Mean synapses per connection |
|------------------------|--------------------------:|---------------------------:|-----------------------------:|
| **L23_CHC**            | **L2_TPC:B**             | 100.0                      | 7.33                         |
| **L23_LBC**            | **L2_TPC:B**             | 0.0                        | 0.00                         |
| **L23_NBC**            | **L2_TPC:B**             | 16.67                      | 33.00                        |
| **L23_CHC**            | **L3_TPC:A**             | 100.0                      | 5.00                         |
| **L23_LBC**            | **L3_TPC:A**             | 100.0                      | 33.00                        |
| **L23_NBC**            | **L3_TPC:A**             | 100.0                      | 36.00                        |

Notes:
- Some inhibitory mtypes appear multiple times because the grouping returned multiple post mtypes (L2_TPC:B and L3_TPC:A).
- **L23_LBC → L2_TPC:B** shows zero connection probability and zero synapses, indicating no detected connections for that pair in this circuit.
- For the pairs with 100% connection probability the mean synapse counts differ (e.g., L23_CHC→L3_TPC:A mean = 5.0 synapses, L23_CHC→L2_TPC:B mean = 7.33 synapses).
- One pair (L23_NBC→L2_TPC:B) has a relatively low connection probability (16.67%) but a high mean synapse count (33.0) when connections exist — indicating sparse but strong (many synapses per connected pair) contacts.

---

## Interpretation & suggestions

- The inhibitory mtypes from layer 23 (CHC, LBC, NBC) show strong connectivity onto layer 3 excitatory TPC:A cells (100% for all three), with notably high synapse counts for L23_LBC and L23_NBC onto L3_TPC:A.
- Connectivity from L23 types onto L2_TPC:B is mixed: CHC is fully connected, NBC is partially connected (16.7%), and LBC has no connections detected.
- High mean synapse counts (e.g., 33–36 synapses) suggest clustered or multi-synaptic inhibitory innervation for those connected pairs — potentially strong inhibitory control when present.
- If you want more comprehensive coverage (e.g., include other inhibitory mtypes, other post-synaptic excitatory mtypes, or different edge populations like thalamic inputs), I can:
  - Run the same connectivity analysis grouped by other properties (layer, synapse_class), or
  - Expand pre/post selections to specific node sets (e.g., particular layers or subsets), or
  - Request results with a max_distance filter to limit connections by spatial radius.

Do you want me to:
- Repeat the inhibitory→excitatory analysis grouped by **layer** instead of mtype?
- Expand to include all pre inhibitory mtypes (not only those returned) and all excitatory targets?
- Analyze another edge population (e.g., thalamic inputs)?

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
## Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum — summary of notable papers (2023–2025)

Below are selected recent and relevant studies on neuronal morphology in cerebral regions (neocortex/visual cortex/human cortex) returned by a literature search. Each entry includes a short summary and a link (DOI or journal URL) so you can read the full paper.

### 1) Of mice and men: Dendritic architecture differentiates human from mice neuronal networks  
- **Authors:** Lida Kanari et al.  
- **Year / Source:** preprint (bioRxiv) — DOI: https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.09.11.557170  
- **Summary:** Comparative analysis of dendritic architecture between human and mouse cortical neurons. The study quantifies dendritic branching, compartmentalization and network-level implications; reports significant species differences that affect connectivity and electrical compartmentalization. Useful for cross-species modeling and interpreting scaling differences in cortex.  
- **Link:** [bioRxiv preprint](https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.09.11.557170v3.full)

### 2) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex  
- **Authors:** Alexander S. Ecker et al.  
- **Year / Source:** 2025, Nature Communications (article)  
- **Summary:** Data-driven, unsupervised mapping of dendritic morphology for >30,000 excitatory neurons reconstructed from MICrONS serial-section EM of mouse visual areas (V1, AL, RL). Uses graph-based machine learning to derive low-dimensional morphological “bar codes”, challenging discrete m-type classifications and highlighting continuous morphological variation across excitatory cells. Important for large-scale morphological atlases and linking morphology to circuit function.  
- **Link:** [Nature Communications article](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w)

### 3) Of general human dendritic spine morphology and density (comprehensive analysis)  
- **Authors:** Henner, Koch (listed in search result)  
- **Year / Source:** 2025, Journal of Neurophysiology (full text link in search results)  
- **Summary:** Comprehensive quantification of human dendritic spine morphology and density across cerebral cortical samples. Reports distributions of spine shape classes, regional and layer-specific differences, and implications for synaptic input patterns and plasticity. (Access may require institutional subscription.)  
- **Link:** [Journal of Neurophysiology article](https://journals.physiology.org/doi/full/10.1152/jn.00622.2024)

### 4) The human cerebral cortex morphology in neuropsychiatric disorders  
- **Authors:** G. Aquino (review)  
- **Year / Source:** 2025, Journal of Affective Disorders  
- **Summary:** Review focusing on macroscopic and mesoscopic cortical morphology alterations in neuropsychiatric disorders. Although broader than single-neuron morphology, it links cortical structural measures (thickness, folding) to underlying cellular and dendritic changes reported in the literature—useful for translational context.  
- **Link:** [ScienceDirect preview](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0165032725005269)

### 5) Contrastive learning-driven framework for neuron morphology ... (methods paper)  
- **Authors:** Jiang, Yikang; Tian, Hao; Zhang, Quanbing  
- **Year / Source:** 2025, Scientific Reports  
- **Summary:** Methodological advance applying contrastive learning and deep representation learning to neuronal morphology datasets (likely including cortical neurons). Develops automated embeddings for morphology classification and retrieval, improving robustness to reconstruction variability. Relevant if you need computational tools for morphological analysis.  
- **Link:** [Scientific Reports article](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-11842-w)

### 6) Non-allometric expansion and enhanced compartmentalization of Purkinje cell dendrites in the human cerebellum  
- **Authors:** Albus J. S. (eLife preprint/assessment)  
- **Year / Source:** 2025, eLife reviewed preprint  
- **Summary:** Although focused on cerebellar Purkinje cells (not cerebrum), this high-quality morphological study demonstrates human-specific dendritic compartmentalization and may provide conceptual parallels for cortical neuron comparisons.  
- **Link:** [eLife reviewed preprint](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/105013)

---

## If you want next
- I can fetch the full text (or extract main figures and methods) for any of these papers — tell me which ones and I will retrieve them.  
- I can run a more focused search (e.g., only human neocortex pyramidal cells, or only layer 5 neurons) or return more results (I searched 6 results; I can expand). Which would you like?

## Overview — what you're looking at

You're viewing a list of **cell morphology** entities from the Open Brain Platform filtered to a specific brain region. In other words, these are digital reconstructions (morphological data) of neurons that were traced or reconstructed for that brain region.

### Context extracted
- **Observed entity type:** *cell-morphology*  
- **Brain region ID:** **2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd**  
- The page shows items filtered for that region (parameter `br_av: 477` in the query).

## What \cell morphology\ means here
- A **cell morphology** asset contains the 3D structure of an individual neuron: soma location, dendrites, axon arbors, and sometimes metadata such as species, cell type label, staining or reconstruction method, and contributor.
- These reconstructions are used for visualization, analysis (branching patterns, length, Sholl analysis), building models, and creating circuit models.

## What you can typically do on this page
- Browse available neuron reconstructions for that brain region.
- Open individual entries to see:
  - Metadata (species, donor, brain region mapping)
  - Downloadable files (SWC, NeuroLucida, mesh)

neuroscientists_search.user: Can you check online who are some of the most impactful computational neuroscientists?
neuroscientists_search.ai_response:
## Summary

Here are widely cited, high-impact figures in computational neuroscience (historical + contemporary). I searched recent web sources (Wikipedia, SfN material, review/list articles, conference proceedings) and compiled a concise, categorized list with short notes and links so you can explore further.

> Note: “Impactful” can mean different things (foundational theory, experimental–theory synthesis, methods/tools, community building). The list below mixes pioneers and modern leaders across those axes.

---

## Foundational pioneers (theory, models, biophysics)

- **Alan Hodgkin** & **Andrew Huxley** — Developed the Hodgkin–Huxley model describing ionic mechanisms of the action potential; foundational quantitative biophysics for neurons.  
  - See: classic Hodgkin & Huxley work (Nobel laureates).

- **David Marr** — Founder of theoretical levels of analysis in vision and neural computation; seminal work on computational theory of the cerebellum, retina and vision.  
  - [David Marr — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Marr_(neuroscientist))

- **W. (Wilfrid) R. (or John) von Neumann / early theoreticians** — (contextual: early computational views that influenced neural modeling and theory of computation).  

---

## Models, learning, and neural networks (historical → modern)

- **Donald O. Hebb** — Hebbian learning rule (“cells that fire together…”), conceptual foundation for synaptic plasticity used in modeling learning.

- **David Rumelhart** & **James McClelland** — Major contributors to connectionist models and modern distributed representations; influential in bridging cognitive models and neural plausibility.  
  - See lists of cognitive/computational neuroscientists on Wikipedia.

- **John Hopfield** — Hopfield networks; connectionist attractor dynamics that linked statistical physics and neural computation.

---

## Modern theoretical & computational leaders

- **Terry Sejnowski** — Pioneering computational neuroscientist; contributed massively to learning rules, neural modeling and bridging biology with machine learning.  
  - Example: foundational work on learning algorithms and biologically inspired models.

- **Larry Abbott** — Important contributions in theoretical neuroscience, network dynamics, synaptic plasticity and statistical descriptions of neuronal circuits.  
  - [Larry Abbott — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Abbott)

- **Karl Friston** — Developed the free-energy principle and predictive coding frameworks; large influence in theoretical neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience, and neuroimaging interpretation.

- **Bruno Olshausen** — Sparse coding, efficient sensory representations models relevant to vision and neural coding.

- **Giorgio (or Giacomo) Buzsáki / Wolf Singer / others bridging experiment & theory** — Many leaders combine large-scale electrophysiology and dynamical-systems models (e.g., oscillations, memory systems).

---

## Circuit, systems, and neuroinformatics leaders

- **Kevan A. C. Martin** — Important for multi-level analyses of neocortical circuits and canonical circuit proposals; influential in combining quantitative anatomy, physiology and modeling.  
  - Source: SfN History volume summary (listed in search results).

- **Eve Marder** — Pioneering work on small neural circuits, robustness, variability, and principled computational approaches to conductance-based models.

- **Henry Markram** — Known for large-scale circuit modeling efforts (Blue Brain Project) and attempts at detailed microcircuit reconstructions (controversial but high-profile).

---

## Statistical, coding, and population-level methods

- **Kenji Doya** — Theorist linking reinforcement learning, neural dynamics and neuromodulation; conceptual frameworks used widely in computational models.

- **Kording / Paninski / Pillow / Stevenson / Buzsáki collaborators** — Modern developers of statistical tools and methods for analyzing neural population data, spike-train modeling, GLMs, and encoding/decoding frameworks. (See CNS conference proceedings and J Comput Neurosci special issues.)

---

## Machine learning ↔ neuroscience cross-pollinators

- **Geoffrey Hinton, Yann LeCun, Yoshua Bengio** — While primarily ML researchers, their work on deep learning has had deep influence on computational neuroscience concepts (representational learning, hierarchical models). (Listed in broader cognitive/computational scientist lists.)

- **Demis Hassabis / DeepMind researchers** — Translate neuroscience-inspired approaches into large-scale models; also collaborate with neuroscience labs.

---

## Where to read more (sources I used / recommended starting points)

- Computational neuroscience — Wikipedia (overview and lists of influential figures).  
  - [Computational neuroscience — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_neuroscience)

- Lists of neuroscientists / cognitive neuroscientists (useful to find names by subfield).  
  - [List of neuroscientists — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_neuroscientists)  
  - [List of cognitive neuroscientists — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_neuroscientists)

- Society for Neuroscience / J Comput Neurosci meeting abstracts (CNS conference) for contemporary active contributors and community leaders.  
  - Example: 30th Annual Computational Neuroscience Meeting (CNS*2021) proceedings on PMC.

- Technology Networks listicles and institutional pages (McGill, SfN history) for curated “influential” lists and biographies.

---

## Would you like one of these?
I can:
- Produce a ranked short-list tailored to a specific criterion (most-cited, most influential in theory, in methods, or in neuroinformatics).
- Provide short bios + key papers for any selected names.
- Export a bibliography (DOIs/links) for the top N researchers you pick.

Which would you prefer?

simulation_tutorial.user: How can I simulate on the platform ?
simulation_tutorial.expected_output:
Here is a tutorial on how to simulate on the platform, specifically for simulating a single neuron model:

How to Simulate a Single Neuron Model on the Platform
Access Virtual Lab:

From the homepage, click the "Go to Virtual Lab" button.
Manage Projects:

Click on "Projects" in the left menu to see your projects.
Create a project if none exists.
Ensure you have credits in your project; transfer credits from your virtual lab if needed.
Build a Single Neuron Model:

Click on the "Build" column in the left panel.
Click the "Build" button in the single neuron tile.
Name your model, optionally add a description.
Select the brain region (e.g., primary somatosensory area).
Click "Start building."
Select a 3D reconstructed morphology (M model) and an existing electrical model (E model).
Filter morphologies by type (e.g., L5 TPC-A for thick tufted layer 5 pyramidal neuron).
Select the appropriate E model matching the morphology.
Save the created morph-electric model (M E model).
Simulate the Neuron Model:

Go back to your project homepage.
Click on the "Simulate" tab, then "Single Neuron."
Find your neuron model or search by name.
Click your model and press "New Simulation."
In the simulation window, pan, rotate, and zoom the neuron morphology.
Set experiment and simulation parameters.
Choose predefined current injection protocols or customize current steps.
Add multiple recording locations by clicking on the morphology or using the "Add Recording" button.
Press "Simulate" to run the simulation.
View and Save Results:

The "Results" tab will display recordings from selected locations.
Save recordings or save them to the library for later access.
You can watch the full tutorial video here:
How to simulate a single neuron model (Video)

If you want, I can guide you through any specific step or help you start a simulation on the platform.
simulation_tutorial.ai_response:
## How to simulate on the Open Brain Platform

Below I’ll give a concise, structured guide covering the typical simulation workflow on the Open Brain Platform, common simulation types, what inputs you need, how to build and run a simulation, and tips/troubleshooting.

---

## 1) High‑level workflow (steps)
1. **Decide the simulation target**
   - Single neuron, pair, small microcircuit, microcircuit (region), system, or whole-brain.
2. **Gather or choose digital assets**
   - Morphologies, emodels / me-models (electrical models), synaptome/connection templates, neuron densities, brain region definitions.
3. **Create or select a circuit**
   - Use an existing circuit (EntityCore) or build a new one (specify populations, node sets, connectivity).
4. **Configure simulation parameters**
   - Duration, time step, stimuli (current injections, synaptic inputs, extrinsic drives), recording outputs (voltage traces, spike times, population rates), temperature, random seeds, parallelization settings.
5. **Validate configuration**
   - Check that model/asset IDs refer to valid EntityCore entries and that populations have compatible models.
6. **Run the simulation**
   - Launch via the simulation API/UI. Monitor status (created → pending → running → done/error).
7. **Retrieve and analyze results**
   - Download traces, spike rasters, summary metrics, or view built-in visualizations.
8. **Iterate**
   - Adjust parameters or model composition and re-run as needed.

---

## 2) Typical inputs you must provide
- **Circuit ID** (if using an existing circuit) or full circuit description (populations, node sets, connectivity).
- **Neuron models** (e-model or me-model IDs) for each population.
- **Morphologies** (if using morphology-dependent synapses/propagation).
- **Connectivity specification** (edge populations, connection probabilities, synapse models, number of synapses/boutons).
- **Simulation runtime parameters**
  - Simulation duration (ms or s)
  - Integration time step (dt)
  - Temperature (if model uses temperature dependence)
  - Random seeds (for reproducibility)
- **Stimuli / protocols**
  - Current injection waveforms
  - Poisson or correlated external input
  - Optogenetic perturbations (if modeled)
- **Recording configuration**
  - Which variables to record (membrane potential, ionic currents, spike times)
  - Spatial/temporal resolution
  - Output formats

---

## 3) Recommended sequence when working with circuits (tooling guidance)
- Always start by retrieving the circuit structure:
  - Use the circuit metrics endpoint (obione-circuitmetrics-getone) with level_of_detail_nodes=1 to discover node sets and edge populations.
- Then inspect connectivity summary:
  - Use obione-circuitconnectivitymetrics-getone to get connection probabilities and synapse counts between populations.
- If you need per-neuron data for custom analyses, use circuit-population-data-analysis (note: slow).

This ensures you know what populations and edge populations exist before building the simulation config.

---

## 4) Creating simulation configuration (practical)
- The platform uses structured JSON configuration for simulation runs. A complete configuration must describe:
  - Target circuit (circuit_id)
  - Simulation parameters (duration, dt)
  - Stimuli and their targets
  - Recording outputs and aggregation options
  - Any custom model overrides or parameter changes
- Important: If you ask me to generate a simulation configuration JSON, I will use the platform generator tool to produce the complete configuration for a given circuit ID.

(If you want me to generate one now, tell me which circuit ID to use and a full description of the desired configuration — I'll call the generator tool and return the JSON.)

---

## 5) Running and monitoring simulations
- After submitting a simulation you can monitor its execution state:
  - States include: created, pending, running, done, error.
- For long simulations, consider:
  - Saving intermediate checkpoints if supported
  - Using appropriate parallelization / compute resources
  - Reducing recorded variables (store only what you need) to save I/O

---

## 6) Best practices and tips
- Use validated me-models/emodels matching the brain region/species of your circuit.
- Start with short test runs (e.g., 100 ms) to validate configuration before long runs.
- Fix random seeds to reproduce runs.
- Limit recordings to variables you need. Large morphology-based recordings can produce huge files.
- Document your configuration (parameters, model IDs) so results are reproducible.
- If using atlas-based circuits, resolve brain-region names to EntityCore IDs via entitycore-brainregion-getall (semantic search) — once you have an ID, use that ID consistently.

---

## 7) Troubleshooting common errors
- Simulation fails with \model mismatch\ or missing asset:
  - Verify the referenced model/morphology IDs exist in EntityCore and are authorized.
- Excessive runtime or memory usage:
  - Lower recorded resolution, reduce number of neurons, or use simpler neuron models for tests.
- Non-deterministic results:
  - Set and log seeds for RNGs (connectivity, stimulation).
- Error reading outputs:
  - Confirm output format (HDF5 / NWB / CSV) and use compatible analysis tools.

---

## 8) If you want, I can:
- Generate a complete simulation JSON configuration for a specific circuit (I will need the circuit ID and the full description of the desired simulation).
- Walk you through a concrete example: single‑neuron current clamp, pairwise connectivity, or a small microcircuit.
- Look up available circuits, models, or assets in EntityCore (I will call the appropriate EntityCore tools if you ask — include any IDs or search terms you want me to use).

Tell me which of the above you want next (e.g., “Generate config for circuit_id = <uuid> to run 1 s with Poisson input”, or “Show me available microcircuits”) and I’ll proceed.
